title: 115_hr4558
content: The "Grand Staircase Escalante Enhancement Act" includes provisions for the establishment of Escalante Canyons National Park and Preserve, withdrawals of certain lands, management councils for various monuments, and restoration of land status. It also clarifies definitions and outlines the adherence of federal land managers. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "Management Council" refers to the council established under section 10, and "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. SEC. 4. ESTABLISHMENT OF ESCALANTE CANYONS NATIONAL PARK AND PRESERVE. The Escalante Canyons National Park and Preserve is established within the Escalante Canyons National Monument in Utah to protect historic, natural, scenic, and recreational resources including hunting and grazing. SEC. 5. WITHDRAWALS. Federal land within Escalante Canyons National Park and Preserve is withdrawn from public land laws, mining laws, and mineral leasing laws. SEC. 6. MAP AND LEGAL DESCRIPTION. The Secretary will provide a map and legal description of Escalante Canyons National Park and Preserve to the House and Senate committees. Any minor modifications to the map or description must be reported to relevant authorities. SEC. 7. GRAND STAIRCASE NATIONAL MONUMENT. The Grand Staircase National Monument, spanning 211,983 acres, is established to protect historic, scenic, and natural resources, promote recreation including hunting, and allow for grazing. The Secretary will submit a map to relevant committees for review. The Committee on Energy and Natural Resources of the Senate will receive a map and legal description of the Grand Staircase National Monument. The map and legal description will be treated as part of the title, with minor modifications allowed by the Secretary. Copies of the map and legal description will be available for public inspection at Bureau of Land Management field offices. SEC. 8. KAIPAROWITS NATIONAL MONUMENT. The Kaiparowits National Monument, spanning 551,117 acres, is established to protect historic, scenic, and natural resources, allow for recreation including hunting, and support grazing. The Secretary will provide a map and legal description to relevant committees. The Kaiparowits National Monument, spanning 551,117 acres, is established to protect historic, scenic, and natural resources, allow for recreation including hunting, and support grazing. The map and legal description submitted shall have the same force and effect as if included in this title, with minor modifications allowed by the Secretary. Copies of the map and legal description will be available for public inspection in Bureau of Land Management field offices. SEC. 9. ESCALANTE CANYONS NATIONAL MONUMENT. The Escalante Canyons National Monument, spanning 243,241 acres, is established to protect historic, scenic, and natural resources, allow for recreation including hunting, and support grazing. The Secretary will submit a map to relevant committees after enactment. The Committee on Energy and Natural Resources of the Senate will receive a map and legal description of the Escalante Canyons National Monument. The submitted map and legal description will have the same legal effect as if included in the title, with minor modifications allowed by the Secretary. Copies of the map and legal description will be available for public inspection at Bureau of Land Management field offices. SEC. 10. Establishes the Escalante Canyons National Park and Preserve, Grand Staircase National Monument, Kaiparowits National Monument, and Escalante Canyons National Monument Management Council. The Management Council is established to develop and implement management plans for various national parks and monuments in Utah. It consists of 7 members appointed by the President and other officials. The Management Council for national parks and monuments in Utah consists of 7 members appointed by the President and other officials. The members include representatives from Garfield County, Kane County, a Utah State Legislator, and an at-large representative appointed by the President. Members appointed should not be federal government employees and serve 5-year terms with the possibility of reappointment for up to three consecutive terms. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment process. Members appointed under subsections (c)(2) and (3) of the Management Council for national parks and monuments in Utah serve without pay, except for travel expenses. The chair is selected from these members for a 5-year term, and staff assistance can be requested from Federal employees. The Management Council for national parks and monuments in Utah meets at least once a year, with meetings open to the public and announced in advance. Hunting, fishing, and trapping are allowed in Escalante Canyons National Park and Preserve in accordance with Utah state laws. The Management Council ensures grazing rights for domestic livestock in Escalante Canyons National Park and Preserve, to be administered by the National Park Service in perpetuity according to Utah state laws. SEC. 11. Federal land managers must follow Management Council's plans. SEC. 12. Utah retains jurisdiction over fish, wildlife, and predators. SEC. 13. Public lands excluded from monument reservation are open for various uses. SEC. 14. Hole in the Rock Road. The Secretary will transfer ownership of the Hole in the Rock Road to the State of Utah. Any conflicting provisions in certain Presidential Proclamations are deemed invalid by this Act.
